summary: Richard Ober was associated with CI/OP/DO within an organization (likely the CIA, based on context). In April 1968, he played a role in the creation and distribution of an Identi-Kit composite of James Earl Ray, the assassin of Martin Luther King Jr. Ober requested the composite and later requested the distribution of photographs of Ray to various stations. His involvement appears to be focused on the operational aspects of identifying and disseminating information about Ray following King's assassination.
significance: Richard Ober's significance lies in his role in the identification and dissemination of information about James Earl Ray, the assassin of Martin Luther King Jr. The documents suggest he was involved in the operational aspects of this process, specifically the creation and distribution of Ray's Identi-Kit composite and photographs. While the documents do not directly link him to the JFK assassination, his involvement in a high-profile case like the MLK assassination highlights his role within the organization and his potential involvement in other sensitive operations.
